Effective Monday 15  - Monday 22 November 2021 Northern Territories Greater Katherine and Robinson River including surrounding homelands entered into a full lockdown. Effective Monday 15  - Monday 22 November 2021 Northern Territories (NT) Greater Katherine and Robinson River including surrounding homelands entered into a full lockdown.  You can only leave your home for essential reasons including 1) For one hour of outdoor exercise a day within 5 km from your home with one other person or people from your house.    For the rest of NT there's no limit to how many people can gather indoors or outdoors â but you should keep 1.5 metres from people you donât live with. If you need to be closer than 1.5 metres, keep contact to less than 15 minutes at a time. Recommendations are to try to avoid participating in social gatherings for more than 2 hours at a time.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119175131/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/lockdown-lockout  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119175313/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt

Although there is a lockdown in Northern Territory, there is no public mandate on reduced public transport. Continuing policy is in place where from Monday 1 November, COVIDSafe capacity on all modes in NSW will increase from 50 per cent to around 75 per cent with an increase in service capacities. More green physical distancing dots will be rolled out across the network, allowing you to choose the best places to sit and stand on all modes.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211102091655/https://transportnsw.info/covid-19/covid-19-safer-travel-guidance

No new policy. Continuing policy for fully vaccinated travelers from New Zealand who test negative in pre-departure COVID tests can enter Australia. They would be allowed to skip quarantine in certain jurisdictions like New South Wales, but those conditions may differ in other states and territories. Other countries restricts travel to Australia where travel is only available if you are exempt or you have been granted an individual exemption (even if you have been vaccinated). All travelers entering Australia from overseas will be quarantined in a hotel or designated facility for 14 days. Travelers are required to undertake their mandatory 14-day quarantine at their port of entry.       https://web.archive.org/web/20211102094008/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102094556/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/coronavirus-covid-19-travel-and-restrictions/international-travel-and-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102094513/https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/01/australia-reopens-its-borders-to-new-zealand-and-singapore.html

COVID-19 vaccines will be voluntary and free  The COVID-19 vaccine is free for everyone in Australia. Vaccination providers cannot charge you for the COVID-19 vaccine or your appointments to receive the vaccine.    If your vaccination provider charges for any costs associated with the administration of the COVID-19 vaccination (including booking fees), you should:    contact us by emailing provider.benefits.integrity@health.gov.au,  or call the Provider Benefits Integrity Hotline on 1800 314 808 (9am to 5pm AEST weekdays).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423124712/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting the closure of schools.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "With the consent of His Majesty the Sultan and Yang Di-Pertuan of Brunei Darussalam, it is hereby announced that the following control measures are reinstated for two weeks with immediate effect:    ...    3. Online learning will commenced for schools, other educational institutions, tuition classes, music classes and special needs classes."    Although it is initially unclear whether this directive applies to universities, Universiti Brunei Darussalam, the country's largest university, instituted Covid-19 shutdown measures on 9th August.    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See Universiti Brunei Darussalam (UBD)'s Covid-19 update page, archived at https://archive.vn/MKajg

No significant changes since the general tightening of measures on the 9th of August, except for the suspension of most in-patient dental procedures and services.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August.    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "ii) All officers and staff, whether government or private are required to do work-from-home. Only really needed staff are allowed to go out to work such as,    frontline workers (health sector, security sector, hospitality sector, transport sector)  daily necessities sector (food, retail business)  facilities and utilities sector (electricity, water, telecommunications)  officers at the borders and entrances to Brunei Darussalam  oil and gas and downstream sectors  development sector  agri-food and forestry sectors"    See the Ministry of Health's initial press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU  See the Ministry of Health's press release on dental procedures (dated 15th August), archived at https://archive.vn/BAxD8

Business premises, including workplaces and dine-in services, may open at 50-percent capacity up to a maximum of 200 people until Dec 14. The capacity will be increased to 75-percent up to a maximum of 300 people starting Dec 15.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211211031242/https:/www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/550471/brunei-authorities-extend-ongoing-covid-19-restrictions-and-curfew-measures-through-dec-14-update-34  https://archive.vn/uA4rP

No changes.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August.    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "i) Any public gathering is not allowed. However, exceptions are allowed as follows:    A group of 15 people for funeral management (not COVID-19).  A group of 5 people for the marriage ceremony."    Additionally, "iii) Leaving the house without a significant purpose is not allowed. Only two people from one family are allowed out of the house to buy daily necessities."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU

No changes.    After local transmission cases were found in Brunei on 07 Aug in over a year, public transport capacity was reduced effective from 09 Aug.    Per the press release of 08 Aug by the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications, written in Malay,    "1.3.1 Public transport operators are limited to 50 per cent seating capacity in public transport vehicles."    People are also encouraged to stay at home through the "Operasi Pulih" programme.    See the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/dkRj1  See the Borneo Bulletin's report on Operasi Pulih published on 02 Oct, archived at https://archive.vn/1gQ2L

No changes.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August. People are required to stay at home, except for essential purposes (for example, going to work for essential workers, buying groceries, or attending funerals and weddings).    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "i) Any public gathering is not allowed. However, exceptions are allowed as follows:    A group of 15 people for funeral management (not COVID-19).  A group of 5 people for the marriage ceremony."    Additionally, "iii) Leaving the house without a significant purpose is not allowed. Only two people from one family are allowed out of the house to buy daily necessities."    This is further reiterated under Operasi Pulih, where "The enhanced restrictions to limit movement between 8pm to 4am announced yesterday under Operasi Pulih (Recovery Operation) is aimed at stopping the public from going out to visit and gather with others, with the exception of essential workers who need to go out to work for the good of society.    This was shared by Minister at the Prime Ministerâs Office and Minister of Finance and Economy II Dato Seri Setia Dr Awang Haji Mohd Amin Liew bin Abdullah during a press conference yesterday, in addition to the strengthening of enforcement agenciesâ activities and public cooperation in aiding the government through the newly introduced 24-hour hotline, as well as involvement of penghulus and village heads in monitoring residents, which are important to ensure people reduce movement."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU  See the Borneo Bulletin's report on Operasi Pulih published on 02 Oct, archived at https://archive.vn/1gQ2L

No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane and Vaccinated Travel Lane with Singapore. Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below).    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 18 Nov, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:        Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/2kolO  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

Most foreign nationals, including long-term pass holders, remain banned from entering or transiting Brunei. Exceptions exist for foreigners on business and official travel, studying in Brunei, undergoing medical treatment, and transport operators, among others. Foreigners who can enter Brunei must obtain an Entry Travel Pass with a Bruneian citizen or entity as a guarantor, obtain a negative result from an RT-PCR test within 48 hours before travel, quarantine up to 14 days at designated premises and undergo further RT-PCR tests upon arrival; fully vaccinated travelers may quarantine for a shorter period of seven days. Only vehicles with Transit Permits may pass through the borders. Transport operators who cross the borders frequently must undergo an RT-PCR test weekly.    Fully vaccinated individuals may travel from Brunei to Singapore without quarantine on dedicated Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) flights. Travelers must have remained in Brunei or any other VTL country within the last 14 days, undergo pre-departure testing, and self-isolate until negative results of an on-arrival test arrive. Individuals must apply for a Vaccinated Travel Pass (VTP) before travel, with the exception of returning citizens and residents.    Alternatively, a Reciprocal Green Lane (RGL) scheme with Singapore is in effect, allowing people to travel for business and official purposes to and from Singapore with exemption from quarantine requirements. Travellers from Singapore who have obtained entry approval under the RGL program must take a COVID-19 test upon arrival and remain in isolation until the test returns negative.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211211031242/https:/www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/550471/brunei-authorities-extend-ongoing-covid-19-restrictions-and-curfew-measures-through-dec-14-update-34    The Prime Ministerâs Office (PMO) said non-essential air travel in and out of the country will resume on January 1, 2022, but travel via land and seaports is still suspended.   However, only fully vaccinated residents will be allowed to travel abroad without the need for exit approval from PMO, and their second dose or booster shot must have been given between 14 days to six months prior to the date of travel.    https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1421.83-1425.236

No changes/deviation; Brunei continues to maintain a systematic, coordinated public campaign re: COVID.    The government continues to maintain an overall website where citizens can access any information related to COVID.   https://archive.vn/PwOIW    There is also an overall site on the Ministry of Health's website pertaining to Covid-19 vaccination (the programme, FAQ, public health messaging).  https://archive.vn/5UFPG    The Ministry of Health continues to update COVID case numbers daily (especially since the recent outbreak). See, for example, 18 Nov (https://archive.vn/ywpTG) and 19 Nov (https://archive.vn/lHKG0).    No updates were missing.

No change.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 18 Nov,    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei?  Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200 [sic, current cost as per Brunei's Ministry of Health is BND $50].  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/2kolO  See the Ministry of Health press release on testing cost (22 May), archived at https://archive.vn/kU9pS

According to the US embassy website:    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei?  Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200.  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS.  For more information, contact Bruneiâs Health Advice Line 148, available 24 hours daily, or visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health.  148 line is also available on WhatsApp and Telegram.  Members of the public may also contact Brunei Red Crescent (BRC) COVID-19 Help Desk Lines 8260320, 8260360, 8260370, 8260390, and 8260420, available from 8:30am to 6:30pm daily.  The BRC lines are the supporting line for BruHealth and 148, which is also available on WhatsApp.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211127233729/https:/bn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services-covid-19-information/

Business owners and customers are required to download the BruHealth application. Individuals must scan a QR code when entering or exiting any premises and activate the Bluetooth function on their phones while in public places.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211211031242/https:/www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/550471/brunei-authorities-extend-ongoing-covid-19-restrictions-and-curfew-measures-through-dec-14-update-34

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status."    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 10 Nov,    "Face masks are mandatory at all times in all indoor and outdoor spaces."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/LLpFZ

Facemasks are mandatory in public, but not required when alone or exercising. They will be mandatory after easing of restrictions on Dec 15.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211211031242/https:/www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/550471/brunei-authorities-extend-ongoing-covid-19-restrictions-and-curfew-measures-through-dec-14-update-34    https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1555.15-1555.80

Vaccination groups: Phase 1, 2 and 3 under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy  Phase 1: Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad;  and  Phase 2: teachers; childcare centre staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases  and  Phase 3: individuals aged 18 years and above    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV); Moderna (elasomeran/mRNA-1273)    Brunei's Phase 3 of its Vaccination Strategy, for individuals aged 18 years and above, commenced on 05 July. "[Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot". According to US embassy website:    Has the government of Brunei approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes.  Are vaccines available in Brunei Darussalam for U.S. citizens to receive?  Yes.  Which vaccines are available in Brunei Darussalam?  Oxford-AstraZeneca, Sinopharm, Moderna, and Pfizer-BioNTech.  The COVID-19 vaccine will be provided free of charge to citizens and residents residing in Brunei Darussalam.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211127233729/https:/bn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services-covid-19-information/

No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs."    See https://web.archive.org/web/20210111022516/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Lists/Latest%20news/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=727  See also, Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, archived on Dropbox, at https://www.dropbox.com/s/yri6djij3ieblma/BRN-202103__-MOH-VaccinationStrategyV2.pdf  See also, IMF's summary on the vaccination groups under "Brunei: Reopening of the Economy", archived at https://web.archive.org/web/20210907090853/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  See the Ministry of Health's press release dated 07 Aug, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL

The government is prioritizing front line workers and the elderly for booster jabs, before extending the rollout to the general public.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213055327/https:/thescoop.co/2021/12/06/booster-shots-rolled-out-to-3-6-of-population-so-far/

The 2-week mid-November campaign for teenages is over and Brunei has resumed offering vaccines first and second doses to individuals age 18+ on November 22, 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211129020430/https://thescoop.co/2021/11/02/brunei-reaches-60-percent-vaccination-rate/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129021616/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/COVID-19%20Vaccine/FAQS%20ON%20COVID-19%20VACCINE%20FOR%20CHILDREN_FINAL_EN.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129021811/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/COVID-19%20Vaccine/FAQs%20General%20Covid%2019%20Vaccine_04032021.pdf

The government had previously announced, and maintained that all vaccines would be provided for free to those resident in Brunei, regardless of citizenship.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101213123/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/COVID-19%20Vaccine.aspx  https://web.archive.org/web/20211101235238/https://thescoop.co/2021/04/02/covid-19-brunei-to-begin-mass-vaccination-on-april-3/

Wang Dengfeng, director of the Prevention and Control Office of the Ministry of Education and director of the Department of Physical Education, Health and Arts Education, said on Nov. 13, 2021, that all teachers and students should have their body temperature tested when they enter the school, and all of them should pay attention to their health status and travel trajectory, and strictly implement all measures for the prevention and control of the epidemic in the school. https://web.archive.org/web/20211201024231/http://www.nhc.gov.cn/xcs/fkdt/202111/4ed1e55f05af44e0a4b2d2fc52b99afe.shtml

Wang Dengfeng, director of the Prevention and Control Office of the Ministry of Education and director of the Department of Physical Education, Health and Arts Education, said on Nov. 13, 2021, that all teachers and students should have their body temperature tested when they enter the school, and all of them should pay attention to their health status and travel trajectory, and strictly implement all measures for the prevention and control of the epidemic in the school.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211201024231/http://www.nhc.gov.cn/xcs/fkdt/202111/4ed1e55f05af44e0a4b2d2fc52b99afe.shtml

Shanxi Provincial Health and Wellness Commission declared on 2021-11-28: All tourist places such as attractions and scenic spots, accommodation places such as hotels, guesthouses and B&Bs, and gathering places such as superstores, theaters, bars and Internet cafes should strictly implement preventive and control measures such as wearing masks, testing body temperature, checking health codes and trip cards for all entering personnel, and strictly check the proof of negative nucleic acid tests within 48 hours for those who have a history of travel and residence in medium to high risk areas and cities where the epidemic occurs within 14 days, and those who cannot provide it should not enter and immediately report to the local epidemic prevention and control departments.  https://web.archive.org/http://www.shanxi.gov.cn/ztjj/yqfkzccs/sjzccs/202111/t20211129_946140.shtml

2021.11.26,Shanghai Municipal Culture and Tourism Bureau on the city's suspension of cross-province group travel and "air ticket + hotel" business notice: travel agencies and online travel enterprises should strictly follow the "Travel Agency New Coronary Pneumonia Epidemic Prevention and Control Guidelines (Third Edition)" requirements, from strict to tight, detailed and practical to do a good job in the recruitment of tourists, organization, reception and other aspects of the epidemic prevention and control work, and strictly control the size of the tour group.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206160618/https://www.shanghai.gov.cn/sjzccs/20211126/f211cb72b4f54059b011d4affabb7ceb.html

Shanxi Provincial Health Commission on 2021-12-03 statement: highways, railroads, civil aviation and other transportation stations to strengthen passenger flow guidance, to avoid the gathering of people.  https://web.archive.org/http://www.shanxi.gov.cn/ztjj/yqfkzccs/sjzccs/202112/t20211203_946786.shtml

2021-12-08, Wang Qingxian in the province's new crown pneumonia epidemic prevention and control work television and telephone conference stressed: to strictly control the flow of people gathered, strengthen the prevention and control measures publicity, timely release of risk tips, coordinated arrangements for school winter holidays, team travel and other matters.  https://web.archive.org/web/https://www.ah.gov.cn/zwyw/ztzl/fkxxgzbdgrdfyyq/yqfkzccs/sjzccs/554074651.html

Tianjin Municipal People's Government Air Defense Command Office November 28, 2021 release information: key land port city control: after the study, the implementation of China's key land port city to return to Tianjin 14 days after arrival medical observation, and 1, 3, 7, 14 days to implement nucleic acid testing.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206144011/https://www.tj.gov.cn/sy/ztzl/tjsfyyqfkzt/sjzcwj/202111/t20211128_5735049.html

The Xinji City Council announced on November 30, 2021 the policy for entering the local area: no one who stays in the medium and high risk areas will be allowed to return to Xin.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206152044/http://www.hebei.gov.cn/hebei/15067610/15068061/15069635/index.html

The Office of the Air Defense Command of the Tianjin Municipal People's Government issued information on December 6, 2021: Relevant people should take the initiative to report, and those who come to and return to Tianjin with a negative nucleic acid certificate within 48 hours or a health code "green code" containing negative nucleic acid test information, should take the initiative to report to the community, work units, etc., and cooperate with the implementation of various preventive and control measures such as home isolation (co-isolation of people living together, centralized isolation if they do not meet the conditions of home isolation), new coronavirus nucleic acid test, health monitoring, etc. for 14 days after leaving the exposed place.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206143402/https://www.tj.gov.cn/sy/ztzl/tjsfyyqfkzt/sjzcwj/

December 8, 2021, Shanxi Province Epidemic Prevention and Control Office health tips: insist on not traveling to medium and high-risk areas and places where the epidemic occurs. Try not to travel to the city where the medium and high risk areas are located and where the epidemic occurs in the near future, and if you must go, make sure to do personal protection throughout and implement isolated medical observation after returning to Jin in accordance with the regulations. Other inter-provincial travelers should take the initiative to conduct a nucleic acid test and do personal health monitoring after returning to Jin.  https://web.archive.org/web/http://www.shanxi.gov.cn/ztjj/yqfkzccs/sjzccs/202112/t20211208_947195.shtml

Lin Wei, director of the Department of Health and Quarantine of the General Administration of Customs, said on November 13, 2021: Customs at land border crossings are determined to implement preventive and control policies such as "stopping passengers and passing goods" and "separating people and goods". https://web.archive.org/web/20211201024231/http://www.nhc.gov.cn/xcs/fkdt/202111/4ed1e55f05af44e0a4b2d2fc52b99afe.shtml

Qinhuangdao City Government on November 24, 2021 issued into the local policy: entry personnel, the first place of entry 14 days of intensive isolation medical observation, the end of isolation to return to Qin after the implementation of 7 days of intensive isolation medical observation, after the release of isolation to continue to implement 7 days of home medical observation. If the first place of entry to complete 21 days of centralized isolation, after arriving in Qin continue to implement 7 days of home medical observation. Where there is no 1 person 1 home conditions, to Qin after returning to Qin closed-loop transfer to a designated isolation site for 7 days of centralized isolation medical observation.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206152547/http://www.hebei.gov.cn/hebei/15067610/15068061/15069945/index.html

Wu Liangyou said on November 13, 2021: "Regarding the new coronavirus vaccination work, according to our arrangements for new coronavirus vaccination in the second half of this year, as well as the needs of winter epidemic prevention and control work, we will continue to promote vaccine booster immunization for key populations and new coronavirus vaccination for people aged 3-11 years old, and to realize the key populations 'should receive as much as possible'." At present, 84,395,000 people have been vaccinated for the 3-11 year old population, and 49,440,000 people have been vaccinated for booster immunization, and we will strive to complete the full vaccination of the 3-11 year old population by the end of December. https://web.archive.org/web/20211201024231/http://www.nhc.gov.cn/xcs/fkdt/202111/4ed1e55f05af44e0a4b2d2fc52b99afe.shtml

Take Precautions Now: Prevent the Spread of All Respiratory Illnesses  The potential public health threat posed by COVID-19 is high, globally, nationally, and to our island. Individual risk is dependent on exposure. Everyone in our community can take steps now to prepare for this emerging public health threat by doing everyday preventative measures:  Itâs currently flu and respiratory disease season and CDC recommends getting a flu vaccine, taking everyday preventive actions to help stop the spread of germs, and taking flu antivirals if prescribed.  Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. However, if soap and water are not readily available, use alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.  Avoid touching your mouth, eyes, and nose with unwashed hands.  Avoid close contact with people who are sick.  Practice proper cough etiquette â cover your mouth and nose with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.  Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects or surfaces.  Stay home when you are sick â do not go to work or school.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203202734/https://www.grta.guam.gov/precautionary-measures-department-public-health

Passengers seeking exemption from quarantine under this section must present the following at the port of entry upon arrival:  1. Photo identification (e.g., passport, driverâs license, state-issued identification); and  2. Businesses are also recommended to continue working from home (telework) if able, expand staggered commuting, and take other measures to prevent denseness during commuting and work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203023515/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012156/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020631.html (Tokyo basic measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012221/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.html (Tokyo basic gathering measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012732/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1125hoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa basic measures from Nov 25)

No change to previous policy.  All public events have resumed. The government has provided detailed guidelines on infection control measures to reduce risk of outbreaks, including providing separate entrances and exits, and limiting personnel depending on venue capacity.    For events that require attendees to move across the country, the government is encouraging those events to be cancelled. However, if necessary, when holding an event that involves nationwide movement or an event with more than 1,000 participants, event holders may also consult directly with city or prefectural authorities to safely hold the event.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119021214/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041621/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020465.html (Tokyo Oct 31-Nov 30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041636/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020468.html (Tokyo FAQ)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034542/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028taishohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034546/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028eigo.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)

No change to previous policy.  On November 8, Japan has shortened the quarantine period to 3-days for all incoming fully vaccinated travellers. International students on scolarships with Japanese universities are also permitted to enter Japan. However, The government continues to limit the number of people allowed to enter the country per day to 3,500, including Japanese citizens.    For all other non-residents, border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended. For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Nov 5).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112044348/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211108/k10013338331000.html (international students and business quarantine)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119041549/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041148/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/files/100256050.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119041645/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C137.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119041600/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.html

Although Japan had begun permitting international students and business travellers in, on November 28 and 29, they had announce restrictions would come back in place due to concerns over the Omicron variant. Effective November 30, Japan would suspend all entry of planned flights for international students and business travellers for all countries.  Up until this point, Japan still has not permitted entry to those that do not hold a valid VISA and all short-term entry for tourism means continue to be barred. Including naturalized citizens of Japan, the number of individuals Japan had permitted entry had only been 3,500 people a day.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130004647/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211129/k10013366101000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130004816/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C145.html%5C

On November 30, Japan's ban on all entry of planned flights for international students and business travellers comes into effect.  While Japan had announced they would be increasing arriving passengers to 5,000 per day on November 18th, the country will now reduce daily incoming travellers, including naturalized citizens of Japan, back down to 3,500 per day.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203023002/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211130/k10013367681000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130004647/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211129/k10013366101000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130004816/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C145.html%5C  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203022540/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2021/11/18/national/japan-increase-entry-cap-5000/

On December 1st, the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism in Japan will be suspending new bookings on all international flights coming into Japan for the entire month of December. This means that even Japanese nationals, will not be able to return into the country before 2022 if they have not yet booked a flight during December.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203032256/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369861000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203032549/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211202/k10013370951000.html

The government has lifted ban from additional Japanese nationals returning into Japan and on December 4 2021, Japanese airlines have resumed allowed Japanese nationals to book incoming flights up to a maximum of 3,500 people per day.  For all other travellers, Japan continues to prohibit entry for non-Visa travel and limited Visas are being processed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152325/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211203/k10013374241000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152359/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152524/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C157.html

No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 20, p.24).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119042136/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 20).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119042136/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119042254/https://corona.go.jp/action

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Nov 26).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130014630/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130014824/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130014656/https://corona.go.jp/action

Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203024650/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130014824/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203024911/https://corona.go.jp/action

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Nov 26).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152610/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130014824/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152935/https://corona.go.jp/action

On November 12, the Japanese government announces change in testing policy. As a pre-emptive measure in preparations for countering against a sixth wave of infection, free PCR and antigen testing have become available for asymptomatic individuals.    Despite the announcement we cannot find any firm dates when the policy comes in to force. Should dates become clearer at a leter date we will adjust the policy accordingly.    Kishida announced Friday that, while new cases are rising, individuals who canât be vaccinated for health reasons and who donât have symptoms but are concerned they have been infected can receive a PCR or antigen test before taking part in certain economic or social activities.    The plan is part of a greater effort to prepare the country for a sixth wave of the pandemic â and whatever comes afterwards â by bolstering hospitals, procuring more medical staff, expanding its vaccine campaign, administering booster shots and advancing the treatment of those with COVID-19.    âWhile new cases have declined substantially, itâs important to acknowledge the strong possibility that the virus will return and to prepare accordingly,â Kishida said Friday.    Itâs not exactly clear who will be eligible and under what circumstances, but Kishida said Friday that the decision will be left to local governments, who have been directed to execute the plan at the latest by the end of March 2022.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211114022125/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2021/11/12/national/covid19-policies-free-testing/    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119050612/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/politics/20211107-OYT1T50148/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119050745/https://toyokeizai.net/articles/-/469112  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119042821/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211115/k10013349111000.html (logistics for free asymptomatic testing)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112050813/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211108/k10013339271000.html (considerations for asymptomatic testing)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119050557/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119045214/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html

While the federal government in Japan is calling on individual locals to prepare for the administration of free PCR test, prefectures have by the end of March 2022 to fully implement the policy.  In Tokyo, the government has announced free PCR testing will become available for those who cannot be vaccinated by mid-December in preparations for the sixth wave of infections.  In Mie, free PCR testing for asymptomatic individuals who live, work, or attend school in the prefecture are eligible from October 11, 2021 to December 10, 2021.  In Tokushima, free PCR testing for asymptomatic individuals is in place but only for those returning into Tokushima prefecture by December 31, 2021.  In Kagawa, the government has announced they will provide free PCR testing for asymptomatic returning individuals into Kagawa from December 6.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130020746/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211125/k10013360981000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130022324/https://www.pref.mie.lg.jp/KANSENJO/HP/m0348600003_00006.htm (Mie)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130021340/https://www.pref.tokushima.lg.jp/ippannokata/kenko/kansensho/5048105/ (Tokushima)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130021740/https://jizenpcr-tokushima.jp/ (Tokushima)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130022011/https://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/14478063 (Kagawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130021958/https://www.fnn.jp/articles/-/274262 (Kagawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130022533/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130022547/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html

Nagano and Shimane prefectures have announced they will be offering free PCR testing for those returning home for the end of the year from outside the prefecture. Testing will be available until December 31, 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203034053/https://www.nbs-tv.co.jp/news/articles/2021120200000002.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203034116/https://www.sanin-chuo.co.jp/articles/-/130101

The Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare has announced they will gradually be reducing the cost of PCR testing for those asymptomatic, and these tests will be partially covered by the public medical insurance.   The current 18,000 yen will be reduced to 13,500 yen from December 31, and 7,000 yen from April 2022. Those symptomatic who have symptoms such as fever or have been identified as a close contact do not have to pay for PCR testing.  The government is also considering allowing rapid antigen tests to be purchased online by companies and restaurants to expand widescale testing.    Free PCR testing in Kagawa to all those asymptomatic and returning to the region will operate from December 6 to December 22 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213161801/https://www.nikkei.com/article/DGXZQOUA0893N0Y1A201C2000000/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213160925/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211207/k10013377321000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213161811/https://www.city.mitoyo.lg.jp/kakuka/kenkofukushi/kenko/8/corona/9059.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213161939/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213162005/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html

60% of all cases in Tokyo are not traced and do not have known infection routes. There is no evidence that contact tracing in Tokyo has improved.  In Osaka, in preparations for a sixth wave, contact tracing has been outsourced to private companies to help with the efforts reaching out to potential close contacts.    Early during the 5th wave, for many wards in Tokyo, close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities and also have shifted focus in making sure those severely ill are properly traced.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119043622/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/local/kansai/news/20211118-OYO1T50021/ (contat tracing efforts in Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070133/https://mainichi.jp/articles/20211022/k00/00m/040/091000c (current contact tracing efforts in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041736/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html

On December 3, the Tokyo Metropolitan Governmnet held an emergency meeting in preparatons for the Omicon variant. The government announces contact tracing personnel will increase from what is now currently 1750 to approximately 3400 workers in order to comprehensively trace close contacts within Tokyo.    Other prefectures such as Osaka, Hyogo, and Kyoto have also been expanding contact tracing support staff and additional training in preparations for a sixth wave.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213155146/https://www.nikkei.com/article/DGXZQOCC0375T0T01C21A2000000/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213160731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211207/k10013379001000.html (contact tracing efforts in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213160820/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211210/k10013383221000.html (contact tracing efforts in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213155717/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/local/kansai/news/20211118-OYO1T50021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213155749/https://www.mbs.jp/news/kansainews/20211209/GE00041439.shtml  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213160834/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html

On November 11, the government authorizes the Pfizer vaccine to be used for third dose vaccination set to begin in December.  Third dose inoculations are being prepared to be administered beginning December 2021. The priority for third dose vaccinations begin from the order of those who received their second doses 8 months prior (or more). The groups are as follows:  - Medical workers (first vaccinated in Feb) will be vaccinated from Dec.  - Elderly (first vaccinated in April) will be vaccinated from Jan 2022.  - Those with other priority inoculations including those with underlying illnesses.    Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054416/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211111/k10013343621000.html (Pfizer third dose)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004111/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211101/k10013330171000.html (third dose)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106042219/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054622/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054719/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)

The government announces vaccination for 5-11 year olds are currently under the review process and is expected to begin February 2022 at the earliest.    Third dose inoculations are being prepared to be administered beginning December 2021. The priority for third dose vaccinations begin from the order of those who received their second doses 8 months prior (or more). The groups are as follows:  - Medical workers (first vaccinated in Feb) will be vaccinated from Dec.  - Elderly (first vaccinated in April) will be vaccinated from Jan 2022.  - Those with other priority inoculations including those with underlying illnesses.    Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose. There are also no-reservation vaccination clinics available for non-Japanese speakers with clinic attendees who are able to communicate in multiple foreign languages.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044541/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211117/k10013351001000.html (5-11 year olds)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044634/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211115/k10013348971000.html (non-Japanese speakers)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004111/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211101/k10013330171000.html (third dose)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106042219/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054622/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054719/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)

In preparations for to begin third dose vaccinations on December 1, 2021, governments of each regional local have been sending out vaccination invitations to medical professionals across the country. Previously the government had announced that only those who had received their second dose 8-months prior qualify for third doses at this time. However, they have since revised this timeline to 6-months for targeted personnel that either work or reside in places identified as high transmission risk such as long term care homes or medical institutions.    As of November 22, 2021, 76.2% of all of Japan's population has received 2-doses.  Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose. There are also no-reservation vaccination clinics available for non-Japanese speakers with clinic attendees who are able to communicate in multiple foreign languages.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211129185518/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211122/k10013357501000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129185921/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211124/k10013359281000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129190056/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211122/k10013357771000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129190256/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129190233/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.htm (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129190302/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)

On December 1, third doses begin being administered to healthcare workers. The government is targeting a total of 1.04 million medical staff in December.  In January, 2 million medical workers, 610,000 elderly people aged 65 and over, and 420,000 people aged 64 and under who received the second vaccination early will become eligible.  In Feburary, 1.83 million medical workers and 11.6 million elderly people, 730,000 under 64 years old will be eligible.  In March, 890,000 medical workers, 16.24 million elderly people, 64 years old or younger In addition to 4.35 million people, 1.68 million people who are "work-related inoculations" conducted at companies and universities are also eligible.  In April, 3.13 million elderly people, 11.94 million people under 64 years old, 5 million occupational inoculations will be eligible.  In May, 580,000 elderly people, 14.62 million people under 64 years old, 1.55 million occupational inoculations will be eligible.  In June, 350,000 elderly people, 12.73 million under 64 years old, and 2.48 million occupational inoculations will be eligible and continue until September 2022.    Mass vaccination sites operated by the Self-Defence Forces in Tokyo and Osaka have now closed. All vaccination sites continue and be operated by prefectural and municipal governments.    Children age 5-11 in Japan will likely begin vaccinations in February 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203031729/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369451000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203032146/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369651000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203033017/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211130/k10013368491000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211202173408/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211202/k10013370651000.html

No change to previous policy. On December 1, third doses begin being administered to healthcare workers. The government is targeting a total of 1.04 million medical staff in December.   As of December 12, the Japanese government reports third doses have been administered 52,737 times nationwide to frontline healthcare workers.    Municipal and prefectural inoculation centres continue to be available for all those 12+ who wish to receive their first or second dose of the vaccine.  Children age 5-11 in Japan will likely begin vaccinations in February 2022 once approval has been completed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213154324/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203031729/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369451000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203032146/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369651000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211202173408/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211202/k10013370651000.html

No change to previous policy.  Some visitation at elderly care homes continue to be restricted. The government is considering the resumption of visitations for fully vaccinated visitors.    Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of November 8, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly also continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Supply infection prevention items such as masks, other PPE, and disinfectants,  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054033/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211110/k10013341201000.html (visitations for fully vaccinated visitors)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044234/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044210/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054300/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/

Beginning November 24, the government allows visitations at long-term care homes restricted to visitors who have been fully vaccinated with two doses of the COVID-19 vaccination or have had a negative PCR test prior to the visitation.    Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of November 8, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly also continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Supply infection prevention items such as masks, other PPE, and disinfectants,  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130023257/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211125/k10013360411000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044234/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130023010/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html

No change to previous policy. The government now allows visitations at long-term care homes restricted to visitors who have been fully vaccinated with two doses of the COVID-19 vaccination or have had a negative PCR test prior to the visitation.    Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of November 8, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly also continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Supply infection prevention items such as masks, other PPE, and disinfectants,  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130023257/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211125/k10013360411000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203030348/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203030409/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html

In response to global COVID-19 developments, the Cambodian Ministry of?Health announced the following guidelines effective as of November 29, 2021:    Effective 29 November, in order to curb the spread of the COVID-19 Omicron variant, all travelers who have been physically present or have transited Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Zimbabwe, Malawi, Angola and Zambia will be prohibited entry into the Kingdom of Cambodia.  The public is directed to wear masks, use?hand sanitizers and?practice?social distancing.  Shops, restaurants, cafeterias, supermarkets,?banks?and other commercial areas?must?require customers to?wear masks, use?hand sanitizer, and engage in social distancing. Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Laos? Yes    If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes    For information on limited humanitarian exemptions to U.S. Centers for Disease Controlâs (CDC) requirement that all U.S. bound travelers present a negative COVID-19 test  U.S. citizens can obtain a COVID-19 test in Laos at The National Center for Laboratory and Epidemiology (NCLE)  in Vientiane. The following information of U.S. citizens is needed to obtain a COVID-19 test: 1. Copy of Passport, 2. Itinerary, 3. A fee of 650,000 Lao kip (approximately $65) may be necessary for U.S. citizens. There are some exceptions to the cost of testing for diplomatic travelers.    A physical copy of test result will be available to pick up within 3 to 5 hours after collection of the sample (for urgent cases, results can be obtained within one hour)    The National Center for Laboratory and Epidemiology (NCLE) is the central authority for COVID-19 in Laos (tel: 021-312351.)  In order to be tested for COVID-19, you must qualify under the following testing criteria:    All new entrees to Laos;  People who have symptoms of COVID-19;  People with severe acute respiratory infection;  People who will travel abroad (and are approved by the Government of Laos COVID-19 Task Force)  There may be fees for each COVID-19 test of up 1.2 million Lao kip (approximately $130), depending on your visa class.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210913134902/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Spearheaded by an MP, a township in Mandalay Region, has set up a collaborative working team involving township departments, local CSOs, and volunteers; a centralised surveillance and communication structure throughout all its wards/villages; 14-day quarantine facilities for overseas returnees; wash facilities in wet markets; and an information campaign engaging local community leaders including monks. It is great that such initiatives are being introduced by communities, but such initiatives will not be found everywhere.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210806082130/https://www.theigc.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Hein-2020-coronavirus-report.pdf
https://web.archive.org/web/20211108172959/https:/www.mohs.gov.mm/Home  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129141507/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Burma? If so, are test results reliably available with 72 hours? â YES    https://web.archive.org/web/20211129141507/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  However, due to limited testing, the number of confirmed cases is lower than the true number of infections.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211020233049/https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus/country/myanmar
https://web.archive.org/web/20211129141507/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Ministry of Health and Sports is conducting disease surveillance and surveillance activities to identify those who have been in close contact with laboratory-confirmed patients for the prevention and control of COVID-19 disease. In doing so, we are identifying those who have been in close contact with the patient for 2 days before the onset of symptoms and within 14 days after the onset of symptoms, based on the recommendations of the World Health Organization (WHOID).    The laboratory-confirmed patients and their families and their places of residence; People who worked together Close contacts Strict home quarantine is being monitored for those who travel together during the trip. The participation of all members of the public, including family members, is especially needed in such monitoring.    Therefore, the Ministry of Health and Sports is announcing the visit to public places within 2 days before the onset of symptoms and 14 days after the onset of the symptoms of laboratory confirmation patients, and urges the public who have been in contact with these patients to contact the nearest administration and health department as soon as possible.       https://web.archive.org/web/20211011034039/https://mohs.gov.mm/page/8509
https://web.archive.org/web/20211129141507/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Have Burmese authorities approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  â YES    Burmese authorities previously received approximately 3 million Covishield/AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine doses in early 2021. Vaccination is prioritizing 36.9 million people aged 18 above in the country. And over 24 million doses have been administeredâ9.56 million people who have received two doses and 5.13 million people who have received doses.    Myanmar signed a sales contract with the Peopleâs Republic of China to buy 24 million doses of Sinopharm vaccine, and all of them have arrived.      First, vaccination prioritized those aged 55 and above, and people aged 45 and above started receiving jabs on October 17.    Since September 14, 2021, vaccination coverage has been accelerated setting groups of priority such as those aged 55 and above, the disabled, members of the ethnic armed groups and their family members, migrant people, refugees and those suffering from critical diseases and non-communicable diseases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129154647/https://elevenmyanmar.com/news/956-million-people-fully-vaccinated-till-nov-13-in-myanmar

Mongolia has officially lifted the restriction on inbound/outbound travel starting from June 1, 2021. However, due to COVID-19 exposure in Erlian city, Inner Mongolia, the Zamyn-ude and Erlian border has been closed down starting from October 14, 2021 for an indefinite period of time. Auckland remains at Alert Level 3 Step 2.     The rest of New Zealand is at Alert Level 2    Schools  Akonga (students) in Years 11, 12 and 13 in Alert Level 3 areas are able to return to school. Akonga who are at higher risk of severe illness from COVID-19 should continue to learn from home, unless they are fully vaccinated.    Tamariki (children) and rangatahi (young people) in Years 1 to 10 should continue to learn from home â unless their parents or carers need to go to work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211122172733/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/alert-level-3/alert-level-3-steps-1-to-3/

Auckland remains at Alert Level 3 Step 2.   The rest of New Zealand is at Alert Level 2    At Step 2, retail can open, with customers keeping 2 metres apart. Staff and customers are required to wear face coverings. Outdoor organised exercise classes, like yoga and bootcamps, can expand to 25 people (including instructors), with 2-metre physical distancing required.    At Step 2, customers cannot enter business premises to consume food, regardless of whether they are seated indoors or outdoors, or if they are bringing their own food.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211122172733/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/alert-level-3/alert-level-3-steps-1-to-3/

"2 key updates for the Red setting:   -There will no longer be a cap of 100 people who can visit a public facility at Red at any one time (this includes zoos, museums, public swimming pools and libraries). Instead, the capacity limit will be based on the number of people who can visit based on 1m physical distancing.   -Gathering limits at Red, including outdoor and indoor gatherings, have been increased from 10 people to 25 people where My Vaccine Passes are not used. The limit where Vaccine Passes are used is still 100 people."  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206172250/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/update-on-covid-19-protection-framework-sector-guidance/  "Gatherings and visits, such as at home, church, and sport locations, can go ahead at Orange, with restrictions."  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206172754/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-orange/  "Northland, Auckland, Taupo and Rotorua Lakes Districts, Kawerau, Whakatane, Opotiki Districts, Gisborne District, Wairoa District, Rangitikei, Whanganui and Ruapehu Districts will move in at Red.  The rest of the North Island will move in at Orange.  The whole of the South Island will move in at Orange."  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206172420/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/traffic-light-settings-announced/

The Eastern Highlands Provincial Education board has suspended all basic education including elementary, community and primary schools for the 2021 academic year.  According to a circular sent out by the Provincial Education Director Albert Wesley numbered, 18 of 2021, the PEBâs decision follows the Provincial pandemic controller John Gimiseveâs order to continue the lockdown for the next 14 days starting today.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211129071809/https:/edu.pngfacts.com/education-news/eastern-highlands-suspends-basic-education-academic-year

The Eastern Highlands Provincial Education board has suspended all basic education including elementary, community and primary schools for the 2021 academic year.  According to a circular sent out by the Provincial Education Director Albert Wesley numbered, 18 of 2021, the PEBâs decision follows the Provincial pandemic controller John Gimiseveâs order to continue the lockdown for the next 14 days starting today (November 1, 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211129071809/https:/edu.pngfacts.com/education-news/eastern-highlands-suspends-basic-education-academic-year

From Sunday (07 November), a two-week lockdown will be in effect in the autonomous region of Bougainville. Larger markets will be closed, shops must comply with hygiene regulations.      https://archive.vn/m9pK0#selection-599.1-599.361

Papua New Guinea will impose lockdown measures in the Autonomous Region of Bougainville due to COVID-19 activity Nov. 7-21. Under the measures, a nightly 20:00-06:00 curfew will be in effect. The Buka, Kokopau, Arawa and Buin main markets must close. All other businesses and government offices may remain open with health protocols in place. Essential workers and shipping services may continue operations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211209171032/https://www.garda.com/fr/crisis24/alertes-de-securite/542401/papua-new-guinea-officials-to-implement-covid-19-lockdown-and-curfew-measures-bougainville-nov-7-21-update-41
Public events are cancelled. Restriction on gatherings of more than 20 people.    https://archive.vn/kDWXQ

Papua New Guinea continues to implement restrictions nationwide as of Nov. 6 amid ongoing COVID-19 activity. From November 7, 2021, Papua New Guinea will impose lockdown measures in the Autonomous Region of Bougainville due to COVID-19 activity.  Public transport can operate 07:00-15:00.     Transport may continue between Central Province and the National Capital District (NCD) and Kerema Open Electorate, Gulf Province. Officials limit capacity on public transport services. Police have threatened to impound any vehicle that violates capacity limits, though compliance and enforcement vary.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211209171032/https://www.garda.com/fr/crisis24/alertes-de-securite/542401/papua-new-guinea-officials-to-implement-covid-19-lockdown-and-curfew-measures-bougainville-nov-7-21-update-41

PNG citizens who have not been fully vaccinated or partially, or persons who have been in a high-risk country in the last 14 days must quarantine on arrival for 14 days. Persons who test positive for COVID-19, on their test upon arrival, shall be quarantined. Passengers arriving into PNG who are fully vaccinated, and are not been in a high-risk country in the last 14 days,  are not required to quarantine on arrival.     https://archive.vn/ZOuc4

As of November 7, the government only permits citizens, permanent residents, and fully vaccinated foreign nationals to enter the country; tourist travel remains banned.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211209171032/https://www.garda.com/fr/crisis24/alertes-de-securite/542401/papua-new-guinea-officials-to-implement-covid-19-lockdown-and-curfew-measures-bougainville-nov-7-21-update-41     https://web.archive.org/web/20211209172512/https://www.smartraveller.gov.au/destinations/pacific/papua-new-guinea

All financial institutions agreed to provide relief of 3 months on loan repayments and interest payments to customers who have lost their jobs, on a case-by-case basis. Other measures that will be eased as part of the Government's plan to live with Covid-19 include doing away with zones or increasing zone capacity for event participants.    The new protocol, known as the vaccination-differentiated safe management measures (VDS) + Test, was announced by the authorities on Monday (Nov 15), as part of a plan to trial greater allowances at activities for those who are fully vaccinated."
